Comments_List: Through guest speakers and talks lead by unit staff, we were able to develop our own sense of leadership and character through countless stories, advice, and scenarios through the semester. Whether it was in Sudler Hall, on the firing range, or in an obstacle course, this course tested our ability to lead and follow, as well as develop our strengths and identify our weaknesses as future Naval Officers.
It is taught professionally and as painlessly as GMT's can be.
The strengths would have to be the depth of experience behind the staff and guest speakers who would give talks each week, as well as the off-campus labs such as the LRC, firing range, and O-course.
This class is an NROTC requirement, so, more accurately, I would recommend NROTC because it is a fantastic program. This class would come with that.

This lab is intellectually challenging and plentifully insightful. In terms of both workload and rigor, it is probably up there with the most famed labs at Yale, such as Physics 165L. At moments I couldn't decided whether I was engaged in philosophical dialogue with Socrates or in a Froco meeting. Overall, one of my favorite courses at Yale.
The only thing that would prevent me from recommending this to another Yale student is the lack of course credit. Outside of that, the class is fantastic.
